§2 For the meaning of existimatio see on Blc i. 16. 5 supr. As a matter of fact, minutio existimationis, which was generically denoted by the term ignominia, most usually resulted from a citizen's getting into a position in which the Edict branded him with infamia, Dig. 3. 2. 1. 'Infamia attached, in consequence of a judicial sentence or something equivalent (infamia iuris) to all persons condemned in a iudicium pub· -licum (Dig. 48. 1. 7), or in any oi the civil actions specified in the text ·(to which must be added the delictual action lor sepulcri violatio, and, for the older law, the actio fiduciae, Gaius iv. 182), or found guilty oi usury, Cod. 2. 12. 20, or ignominiously discharged from military service (Dig. 3. a t), guardians removed as suspecti ob dolum, Bk. 1. 26. 6 supr„ and bankrupts (p. 377 supa). Other persons became infames apart from anything in the nature osa judicial sentence (infamia immediata), eg. wives taken in adultery, Dig. 23. 2. 43. 12 and r3; guardians who married their female wards while under age, ib. 66. pr.; and persons who violated a transactio (p. 387 supr.) made under oath, Cod. 2. 4 4¹·
